Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref447113409} and \REF{bkm:Ref441302833} illustrate ka{}- nominalizations used as nouns in context:
Content 1: \gsrc Daw ino na \textbf{kadayad} mga dikurasyon an na mga paniin. | \gll Daw ino na \textbf{ka-dayad} mga dikurasyon an na mga paniin. | \gls if/when what LK NR-good PL decoration DEF.M LK PL shells | \glt ‘What \textbf{beauty} of the shell decorations!’
Content 2: \gsrc Tagan kay ta \textbf{kabaskeg} ta ame na mga lawa para mag-ubra kay... | \gll ∅-atag-an kay ta \textbf{ka-baskeg} ta ame na mga lawa para mag--ubra kay... | \gls T.IR-give-APL 1P.EXCL.ABS NABS NR-strong NABS 1P.EXCL.GEN LK PL body for I.IR-work 1P.EXCL.ABS | \glt ‘Give us \textbf{strength} for our bodies in order for us to work ...'

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref116398555}{}-\REF{bkm:Ref116398718} illustrate some ka{}-...-én nominalizations in context:
Content 1: \gsrc Piro ta \textbf{kasàkeén} ta iran na ubra uļa danen namasmasi na iran na bata may kalain ta beet ki danen. | \gll Piro ta \textbf{ka-s}à\textbf{ke-én} ta iran na ubra uļa danen na-masmas--i na iran na bata may ka-lain ta beet ki danen. | \gls but NABS NR-busy-NR NABS 3P.GEN LK work NEG.R 3P.ERG A.HAP.R-notice-XC.APL LK 3P.GEN LK child EXT.IN NR-bad NABS inner.being OBL.P 3p | \glt `But in the \textbf{business} of their work they did not notice that their child had bad feelings towards them.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Katamarén} din paryo ta iya na amay. | \gll \textbf{ka-tamad-én} din paryo ta iya na amay. | \gls NR-lazy-NR 3S.GEN same NABS 3S.GEN LK father | \glt ‘His/her \textbf{laziness} is like his/her father.’

Knowledge Point: The following examples illustrate some of these constructions in context. Example \REF{bkm:Ref419298360} illustrates the form tumanan used as a noun:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref106949019} illustrates the form kaguļangan ‘mature (land)’, based on a prop\-er\-ty-concept root\is{property-concept roots (adjectives)}\is{adjectives}, and kakauyan ‘forest’ based on a nominal root both functioning as nouns:
Content 1: \gsrc Amo i isya na ayep naan gaistar ta \textbf{kaguļangan} o \textbf{kakauyan}. | \gll Amo i isya na ayep naan ga-istar ta \textbf{ka-guļang-an} o \textbf{ka-kauy-an}. | \gls monkey DEF.N one LK animal SPAT.DEF I.R-live NABS NR-mature-NR or NR-tree-NR \glt ‘Monkeys are one (kind of) animal living in \textbf{oldest} \textbf{(virgin} \textbf{forests)} or \textbf{places} \textbf{with} \textbf{many} \textbf{trees}.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref106949274} illustrates the form batuan ‘rocky place’, functioning as a location:
Content 1: \gsrc Niog nai derse nang pļapa din tak naan gatubo ta \textbf{batuan}. | \gll Niog nai derse nang pļapa din tak naan ga-tubo ta \textbf{bato-an}. | \gls coconut D1ABS small.PL only frond 3S.GEN because SPAT.DEF I.R-grow NABS rock-NR | \glt ‘This coconut tree, its fronds are small only because it grows in a \textbf{rocky} \textbf{place}.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref106949527} illustrates the verbal root ugsak ‘put inside’ nominalized with -an, to refer to a location.
Content 1: \gsrc Gakamang a ta kaļaw daw \textbf{ugsakan} ta ummay na ega. | \gll Ga-kamang a ta kaļaw daw \textbf{ugsak-an} ta ummay na ega. | \gls I.R-get 1S.ABS NABS winnowing.basket and put.inside-NR NABS unmilled.rice LK dry | \glt `I got a winnowing basket and a \textbf{container} of unmilled rice that was dry.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, example \REF{bkm:Ref106950024} illustrates the noun bata ‘child’ with -an meaning ‘group of children usually having the same parents’, while \REF{bkm:Ref106950027} illustrates the same root with ka-…-an meaning ‘group of many children’, or ‘youth’, usually having different parents:
Content 1: \gsrc May bata daen appat buok, darwa bai, darwa man mama. Ta, tak ubos en may sawa \textbf{bataan} daen, darwa nang en bilin an baļay en. | \gll May bata daen appat buok, darwa bai, darwa man mama. Ta, tak ubos en may sawa \textbf{bata-an} daen, darwa nang en bilin an baļay en. | \gls EXT.IN child 3P.ABS four piece two female two too male so because all CM EXT.IN spouse child-NR 3P.GEN two only CM left SPAT.DEF house CM | \glt `They have four children, two female, two male too. So, because all their \textbf{children} have spouses, just (they) two only are left at the house.’
Content 2: \gsrc Anduni mga bag-o tubo na mga \textbf{kabataan} uļa gataod ta iran na isigkaittaw. | \gll Anduni mga bag-o tubo na mga \textbf{ka-bata-an} uļa ga-taod ta iran na isigka-ittaw.\footnotemark{} | \gls now/today PL new grow LK PL NR-child-NR NEG.R I.R-respect NABS 3P.GEN LK fellow-people | \glt `Now/today, the new generation of \textbf{children} do not respect their fellow people.’

Knowledge Point: There are other nouns that seem to have the ka{}- nominalizer and either -en or -an suffix but are not easily divided into morphemes. These may have been borrowed from other languages (notably Hiligaynon) or are simply lexicalized. A selection of such words is given in \REF{bkm:Ref51161274}. An example of an irregular formation is given in \ref{ex:kindness}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Future patient nouns may also be derived from nominal roots (examples in \ref{bkm:Ref117346657}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The suffix -én/-ón can also derive adjectives as described in \chapref{chap:modification}, \sectref{bkm:Ref117512242}. Examples \REF{bkm:Ref116398789} and \REF{bkm:Ref116398793} illustrate some future patient nominalizations from the corpus:
Content 1: \gsrc Gatanem kay ta mga saging daw mga \textbf{laswaén}. | \gll Ga-tanem kay ta mga saging daw mga \textbf{laswa-én}. | \gls I.R-plant 1P.EXCL.ABS NABS PL banana and PL cook.fish.stew-NR | \glt ‘We planted bananas and \textbf{fish-stew-vegetables}.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Gulayén} ta Cagayancillo klasi-klasi na mga prutas tampayas puso ta saging, sitaw, bļatong, taļong, kļubay, klabasa, nangka daw duma pa na \textbf{gulayén}. | \gll \textbf{Gulay-én} ta Cagayancillo klasi--klasi na mga prutas tampayas puso ta saging, sitaw, bļatong, taļong, kļubay, klabasa\footnotemark{}, nangka daw duma pa na \textbf{gulay-én}. | \gls vegetables-NR NABS Cagayancillo RED-kind LK PL fruit papaya heart NABS banana yardlong.bean string.bean eggplant bottle.gourd summer.squash jackfruit and other INC LK vegetable-NR | \glt `\textbf{Cooking} \textbf{vegetables} on Cagayancillo, (are) kinds of fruits, papaya, flower (lit. heart) of banana, yardlong beans, string beans, eggplant, bottle gourd, summer squash, jackfruit, and other \textbf{cooking} \textbf{vegetables}.’

Knowledge Point: The nominalizing infix <in> occurs after the first consonant of the root.\footnote{As discussed in Chapter 2, in Kagayanen all words begin with consonants. Words that begin with vowel letters in the orthography actually start with an unwritten glottal stop, which is a full consonant in Kagayanen. So, for example, the verb ambaļ has an initial unwritten glottal stop. The infix <in> occurs after the initial glottal stop to form the word spelled inambaļ.} The resulting noun usually refers to something that is affected by the action or process described by the root (examples \ref{bkm:Ref419299508} and \ref{bkm:Ref419299510}). In this sense, <in> is analogous to a past-participle marker. Unlike \isi{Tagalog} and many other Philippine languages, <in> alone has no function as a Transitivity/Modality marker on inflected verbs. Rather, in Kagayanen the corresponding \isi{inflectional} form is the transitive realis pa{}- (see \chapref{chap:verbstructure}, \sectref{sec:transitiverealis}):
Content 1: \gsrc May baļon a na \textbf{linub-ong}. | \gll May baļon a na \textbf{l<in>ub-ong}. | \gls EXT.IN provisions 1S.ABS LK <NR.RES>cooked.cassava | \glt ‘I have some \textbf{steamed} \textbf{cassava} provisions.’
Content 2: \gsrc Daw luto en iran na \textbf{sinin-ad} magtumpok danen daw magkaan. | \gll Daw luto en iran na \textbf{s<in>in-ad} mag-tumpok danen daw mag-kaan. | \gls if/when cook CM 3P.GEN LK <NR.RES>cook.grain I.IR-gather 3S.ABS and I.IR-eat | \glt ‘When \textbf{what} \textbf{was} \textbf{cooked} is already cooked (completely) they gather together and eat.’

Knowledge Point: Like all Kagayanen nouns, nominalizations formed with the infix <in> can function as modifiers (as in \ref{bkm:Ref419299508}). For example, baļad ‘to sun dry’ with <in> becomes binaļad ‘sun dried thing’. This form may occur in the position of a modifier in Referring Phrases, e.g., binaļad na mais ‘sun dried corn’. Examples \REF{bkm:Ref419378020} and \REF{bkm:Ref51233639} are corpus examples illustrating this usage with the roots sugba ‘to roast’ and begkes ‘to bundle’ respectively:
Content 1: \gsrc May baļon a na \textbf{linub-ong}. | \gll May baļon a na \textbf{l<in>ub-ong}. | \gls EXT.IN provisions 1S.ABS LK <NR.RES>cooked.cassava | \glt ‘I have some \textbf{steamed} \textbf{cassava} provisions.’
Content 2: \gsrc Pag-abot nay dya, listo kay eman kaan tak may mga \textbf{sinugba} na sidda. | \gll Pag--abot nay dya, listo kay eman kaan tak may mga \textbf{s<in>inugba} na sidda. | \gls NR.ACT-arrive 1P.EXCL.GEN D4LOC quickly 1P.EXCL.ABS again.as.before eat because EXT.IN PL <NR.RES>roast LK fish | \glt `When we arrived there, quickly we ate again because there were some \textbf{roasted} fish.’
Content 3: \gsrc Masimba anay danen an daw magprusisyon na daļa a santos na Santo Ninyo palibot ta banwa na gadaļa ta \textbf{binegkes} na tanitang. | \gll Ma-simba anay danen an daw mag-prusisyon na daļa a santos na Santo Ninyo pa-libot ta banwa na ga-daļa ta \textbf{b<in>egkes} na tanitang. | \gls A.HAP.IR-worship first 3P.ABS DEF.M and I.IR-procession LK carry INJ statue LK Holy Child T.R-around NABS town/country LK I.R-carry NABS <NR.RES>bundle LK dried.coconut.frond | \glt `They will first go to church and go in a procession carrying the statue, the Holy Child, taking (it) around the town carrying \textbf{bundled} dried coconut fronds.’

Knowledge Point: When <in> occurs on nominal roots referring to units of time, the meaning is plural, with (\ref{bkm:Ref419299808} and \ref{bkm:Ref419299809}) or without (\ref{bkm:Ref441664725}) the \isi{plural} marker mga:
Content 1: \gsrc Ta \textbf{mga} \textbf{binuļan} na gubra mga mama ta simbaan daw iskwilaan malised na uļa angay pangabui ta mga ittaw. | \gll Ta \textbf{mga} \textbf{b<in>uļan} na ga-ubra mga mama ta simba-an daw iskwila-an ma-lised na uļa angay pangabui ta mga ittaw. | \gls NABS PL <NR.RES>month LK I.R-work PL man NABS worship-NR and go.to.school-NR ADJ-distress LK NEG.R fitting living NABS PL person | \glt ‘During the \textbf{months} when the men were working on the church and school (it was) distressing (and) not fitting for the lives of people.'
Content 2: \gsrc Ta una sa na \textbf{mga} \textbf{inadlaw} panliton i pasunod ta maid-id ta mga ittaw ta banwa ta i. | \gll Ta una sa na \textbf{mga} \textbf{<in>adlaw} panliton i pa-sunod ta maid-id ta mga ittaw ta banwa ta i. | \gls NABS first D4NABS LK PL <NR.RES>day baby.ritual DEF.N T.R-follow NABS well NABS PL person NABS town/country 1P.INCL.GEN DEF.N | \glt `In the first (i.e. early) \textbf{days} the ritual of presenting babies to ancestor spirits the people in our town followed (it) well.’
Content 3: \gsrc Piro duma ya na galambay ya na \textbf{tinaon} dili pa gid segeng na pag-ataki ta apo. | \gll Piro duma ya na ga-lambay ya na \textbf{t<in>aon} dili pa gid segeng na pag--ataki ta apo. | \gls but some DEF.F LK I.R-pass.by DEF.F LK <NR.RES>year NEG.IR INC INT extreme LK NR.ACT-attack NABS asthma | \glt `But other past \textbf{years} it was not yet really an extreme attack of asthma.’

Knowledge Point: The infix <in> may combine with the applicative \textit{{}-an}. Only verb roots which require or allow the applicative \nobreakdash-an may be nominalized in this way (see \chapref{chap:stemformingprocesses}, \sectref{sec:applicative-an}). The interpretation of the resulting nominalization depends largely on the nature of the verb root, and is generally consistent with the use of the applicative suffix on Inflected Verbs. For example, as discussed in \chapref{chap:stemformingprocesses}, \sectref{sec:applicative-an}, some transitive verbs require \textit{{}-an} in their normal active-transitive use as main verbs. For this same set of roots, <in>...-an forms a nominalization that refers to the Patient of the verb (\ref{bkm:Ref419300230}-\ref{bkm:Ref419300233}). The stress on such nominalizations is regular---the main stress falls on the penultimate syllable and the secondary stress two syllables to the left.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Tinanuran} ko ya na bata nuļog ta geddan. | \gll \textbf{T<in>anur-an} ko ya na bata na-uļog ta geddan. | \gls <NR.RES>care.for-APL 1S.GEN DEF.F LK child A.HAP.R-fall NABS stairs | \glt `\textbf{The} child I \textbf{cared} \textbf{for} fell down the stairs.’ (lit. `my cared for child')
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Some roots can take either <in> alone or <in>...-an to form a Patient nominalization (\ref{bkm:Ref419300396} and \ref{bkm:Ref447637695}). With <in> alone the patient is presented as more precise and individuated and in some situations is more directly acted upon than the corresponding form with <in>...-an. This meaning difference is comparable to the difference between pa- and pa-…-an for this same class of roots used as inflected verbs (see \chapref{chap:verbstructure}, \sectref{bkm:Ref448124627}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Pinetpet} din na kaoy kamang ta duma na ittaw. | \gll \textbf{P<in>etpet} din na kaoy kamang ta duma na ittaw. | \gls <NR.RES>chop 3S.GEN LK tree/wood get NABS other LK person | \glt ‘His/her \textbf{chopped} wood another person took (it).’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Pinetpetan} din na kaoy nabilin din naan uma nay. | \gll \textbf{P<in>etpetan} din na kaoy nabilin din naan\footnotemark{} uma nay. | \gls <NR.RES>chop-APL 3S.GEN LK tree/wood A.HAP.R-left 3S.ERG SPAT.DEF field 1P.EXCL.GEN | \glt ‘Some of his/her \textbf{chopped} wood s/he happened to leave behind in our field.’

Knowledge Point: On other verbs, <in> plus -an forms a Location or Recipient nominalization. Again, this usage is consistent with the function of -an as an applicative marker (see \chapref{chap:stemformingprocesses}, \sectref{sec:applicative-an}). Examples \REF{bkm:Ref419300326} and \REF{bkm:Ref419300323} illustrate Location nominalizations (the place where something occurs):
Content 1: \gsrc Kada kilem may pagwa kanen an daw indi na mga \textbf{binaylian}. | \gll Kada kilem may pa-gwa\footnotemark{} kanen an daw indi na mga \textbf{b<in>ayli-an}. | \gls each night EXT.IN CAUS-out 3S.ABS DEF.M if/when where LK PL <NR.RES>slow.dance-APL | \glt `Each night he had a presentation wherever there were \textbf{places} \textbf{for} \textbf{dances}.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \footnotetext[13]{The root alin functions as an oblique preposition with the meaning ‘from.’ It also functions as a verb, as in example \REF{bkm:Ref419300323}, meaning ‘come from’, or ‘be from.’}
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{bkm:Ref419380070}, <in> with the verb tudlo ‘teach’ becomes tinudlo referring to what is being taught, which in this example is a dance. In example \REF{bkm:Ref419444251}, <in>...-an with tudlo ‘teach’ becomes tinudluan referring to the recipient of the action, that is, the one taught, which in this example are children.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Tinudlo} din an na sayaw dili dayad. | \gll \textbf{T<in>udlo} din an na sayaw dili\footnotemark{} dayad. | \gls <NR.RES>teach 3S.GEN DEF.M LK dance NEG.IR good | \glt ‘The dance he taught was not good.’ (lit. ‘His/her taught dance ...)
Content 2: \gsrc Yi na \textbf{tinudluan} ko na mga bata kan-o, gatudlo man anduni. | \gll Yi na \textbf{t<in>udlu-an} ko na mga bata kan-o, ga-tudlo man anduni. | \gls D1ABS LK <NR.RES>teach-APL 1S.GEN LK PL child previously I.R-teach also now/today | \glt `These children I taught previously, are teaching also now.’ (lit. ‘My taught children ...”)

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{bkm:Ref447638230} is a riddle, with two possible answers:
Content 1: \gsrc Daw bata pa \textbf{panggulay}. Daw manakem en \textbf{pangbaļay}. Patong. / Tambo. | \gll Daw bata pa \textbf{pang-gulay}. Daw manakem en \textbf{pang-baļay}. Patong. / Tambo. | \gls if/when young INC INST-vegetable if/when older CM INST-house rattan / bamboo.shoot | \glt `When still young (it is) \textbf{used} \textbf{for} \textbf{vegetable}. When older (it is) \textbf{used} \textbf{for} \textbf{the} \textbf{house}. Rattan. / Bamboo shoot.’

Knowledge Point: On roots describing times or activities, pagka{}- creates an action nominalization that refers to the time after something else happens. In this usage, pagka{}- contrasts with pag{}-, which indicates simultaneous or sequential events that are closely related to the previous action (see \chapref{chap:clausecombining}, \sectref{sec:nominalizationsasdependentclauses}). Examples \REF{bkm:Ref116460168} and \REF{bkm:Ref116460171} illustrate some pagka- nominalizations in contrast with pag{}- nominalizations:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \footnotetext{There are two words glossed as ‘again’ in this example. Eman is the marked member of the pair, and refers to the continuation of an action that was interrupted. Isab expresses no particular sense of continuation. In the context of example \REF{bkm:Ref447656201}, eman would have been semantically appropriate in both positions, however we speculate that having two emans in a row would have sounded odd, so the speaker chose to use isab in the second instance, which is also semantically appropriate.}
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Pagkasellem} eman, gapanaw kay isab na miling ta isya na ristaurant. | \gll \textbf{Pag-ka-sellem} eman, ga-panaw kay isab\footnotemark{} na m-iling ta isya na ristaurant. | \gls NR.ACT-NR-morning again.as.before I.R-walk/leave 1P.INCL.ABS again LK I.V.IR-go NABS one LK restaurant | \glt `\textbf{After it became morning} again as before, we left again going to a restaurant.’

Knowledge Point: The affix mag{}- with nouns that indicate a human relationship, such as kinship terms and words such as arey ‘friend’, result in a noun that refers to particular persons who are in that relationship. Some of these nouns express reciprocal and others non-reciprocal relationships. For example, mag{}- with utod ‘sibling’ becomes mag-utod ‘siblings (to each other)’ (\ref{bkm:Ref420509881}); mag- with arey ‘friend’ becomes mag-arey meaning ‘friends (to each other)’, (\ref{bkm:Ref420509947}). These are reciprocal relationships, since each member of the relationship is equal---sibling-to-sibling, or friend-to-friend. An example of a non-reciprocal relationship is mag{}- + inay ‘mother’ yielding mag-inay ‘mother and child(ren)’:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Isya na adlaw, darwa i na \textbf{mag-arey}, Umang i daw Pwikan, namasyar naan ta baybay. | \gll Isya na adlaw, darwa i na \textbf{mag--arey}, Umang i daw Pwikan, na-ŋ-pasyar naan ta baybay. | \gls one LK day two DEF.N LK REL-friend hermit.crab DEF.N and sea.turtle A.HAP.R-PL-visit SPAT.DEF NABS beach | \glt `One day, the two \textbf{friends}, Hermit Crab and Sea Turtle, went strolling on the beach.’

Knowledge Point: The prefix king- is added to a nominal root to form a new noun that refers to the ‘style’ or ‘manner’ of the root noun. This is not a common prefix. Example \REF{bkm:Ref116461310} below is the only instance of this prefix in the corpus. The others are all from conversation, or are elicited. Words formed with king- are not adjectives by the definition given in \chapref{chap:modification}, \sectref{sec:adjectives}, because they do not occur with degree adverbs such as sikad ‘very’:
Content 1: \gsrc Patugtug an ta banda mga tukar an \textbf{kingmanakem} en pugya a.\\ | \gll Pa-tugtug an ta banda mga tukar an \textbf{king-manakem} en pugya a. | \gls T.R-play.music DEF.M NABS band PL music DEF.M style/way-older CM long.ago INJ | \glt `The music the band played was the older people’s style of music of long ago.’

Knowledge Point: The prefix taga{}- forms a noun or modifier that refers to a person who is originally from a location specified in the root. Example \REF{bkm:Ref447688060} is a predicate nominal consisting of a predicate meaning “someone originally from Cagayancillo”, followed by the single Argument:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Taga-Cagayancillo} yaken i. | \gll \textbf{Taga-Cagayancillo} yaken i. | \gls ORIG-Cagayancillo 1S.ABS DEF.N | \glt ‘I am \textbf{originally} \textbf{from} \textbf{Cagayancillo}.’

Knowledge Point: Some writers use a hyphen following taga-, especially when it occurs before a capitalized place name, such as Cagayancillo (\ref{bkm:Ref447688060}) or Negros \REF{ex:negros}. However, this is not consistent \REF{ex:philippines}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Taga-Cagayancillo} yaken i. | \gll \textbf{Taga-Cagayancillo} yaken i. | \gls ORIG-Cagayancillo 1S.ABS DEF.N | \glt ‘I am \textbf{originally} \textbf{from} \textbf{Cagayancillo}.’

Knowledge Point: The suffix -anen is an uncommon and non-productive suffix that designates a person or characteristic associated with the root to which it attaches. It is possibly a reflex of the common Bisayan suffix -anon. It occurs in only six words in Kagayanen, all of which were probably borrowed from \isi{Hiligaynon}. These are illustrated in \REF{bkm:Ref118704475}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In addition to these enclitic and free pronouns, there are two composite personal pronouns used when first person acts on second person---ta kaw is used when both arguments are singular (\ref{bkm:Ref419448603}) and ta kyo is used when the 1\textsuperscript{st} person is singular and the 2\textsuperscript{nd} person is plural (\ref{bkm:Ref419448605}). There are no other situations in which composite pronouns are used.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \footnotetext{The root for this verb is atag. In conversation, the initial vowel normally drops out when a suffix occurs, though this is optional. In example \REF{bkm:Ref420429206}, below, the initial vowel may not drop out because the verb carries no suffix.}
Content 1: \gsrc Paatag din sid-anan din an \textbf{ki} \textbf{yaken}. | \gll Pa-atag din sid-anan din an \textbf{ki} \textbf{yaken}. | \gls T.R-give 3S.ERG viand 3S.GEN DEF.M OBL.P 1s | \glt ‘S/he gave his/her viand to \textbf{me}.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{bkm:Ref419465634} and \REF{bkm:Ref419465636} are identical except that the absolutive case Recipient is expressed with the emphatic pronoun plus demonstrative determiner in \REF{bkm:Ref419465636}. Emphatic pronouns have the same distributional possibilities as full Referring Phrases, while enclitics follow the first major constituent of the immediate phrase. The demonstrative determiner i may be “optional” in this and the following examples, especially in relaxed speech. However, speakers agree that it “sounds better” with the demonstrative determiner:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Tagan din \textbf{yaken} i ta sid-anan. | \gll ∅-atag-an din \textbf{yaken} i ta sid-anan. | \gls T.IR-give-APL 3S.ERG 1S.ABS DEF.N NABS viand | \glt ‘S/he will give \textbf{ME} some viand.’ (Emphasis on ME.)
Content 3: \gsrc Tagan din \textbf{yaken} i ta sid-anan. | \gll ∅-atag-an din \textbf{yaken} i ta sid-anan. | \gls T.IR-give-APL 3S.ERG 1S.ABS DEF.N NABS viand | \glt ‘S/he will give \textbf{ME} some viand.’ (Emphasis on ME.)

Knowledge Point: In example \REF{bkm:Ref419117602}, the verb appears in the intransitive form, so the actor kay is the absolutive argument. Therefore ame is not ergative; rather it occurs after the absolutive pronoun of the same person and number to express strong contrast. Example \REF{bkm:Ref419174393} is similar, but with a first person singular actor. In relaxed speech, the a 1\textsc{s.abs} pronoun may elide before ake.
Content 1: \gsrc Gaatag kay \textbf{ame} ta sid-anan ki kanen. | \gll Ga-atag kay \textbf{ame} ta sid-anan ki kanen. | \gls I.R-give 1P.EXCL.ABS 1P.EXCL.GEN NABS viand OBL.P 3s | \glt ‘\textbf{We} \textbf{ourselves} (rather than someone else) gave some viand to him’.
Content 2: \gsrc Gaatag a \textbf{ake} ta sid-anan ki kanen. | \gll Ga-atag a \textbf{ake} ta sid-anan ki kanen. | \gls I.R-give 1S.ABS 1S.GEN NABS viand OBL.P 3s | \glt ‘I myself (rather than someone else) gave some viand to him/her.’

Knowledge Point: Free pronoun in Oblique role (see also examples \ref{bkm:Ref419117602} and \ref{bkm:Ref419174393} above) \\
Content 1: \gsrc Gaatag kay \textbf{ame} ta sid-anan ki kanen. | \gll Ga-atag kay \textbf{ame} ta sid-anan ki kanen. | \gls I.R-give 1P.EXCL.ABS 1P.EXCL.GEN NABS viand OBL.P 3s | \glt ‘\textbf{We} \textbf{ourselves} (rather than someone else) gave some viand to him’.
Content 2: \gsrc Gaatag a \textbf{ake} ta sid-anan ki kanen. | \gll Ga-atag a \textbf{ake} ta sid-anan ki kanen. | \gls I.R-give 1S.ABS 1S.GEN NABS viand OBL.P 3s | \glt ‘I myself (rather than someone else) gave some viand to him/her.’

Knowledge Point: The non-absolutive demonstrative pronouns function in ergative (\ref{bkm:Ref419468709} and \ref{bkm:Ref419525739}), or oblique (\ref{bkm:Ref420432602} and \ref{bkm:Ref420432613}) roles. Similarly, they function within Referring Phrases (RPs) in the genitive role (\ref{bkm:Ref116482624} and \ref{bkm:Ref420432688}):
Content 1: \gsrc Ambaļ \textbf{ti}, “Marga kon en.” | \gll Ambaļ \textbf{ti}, “M-larga kon en.” | \gls say D1NABS I.V.IR-depart HSY CM | \glt ‘\textbf{This} \textbf{one} said, “(The boat) will depart now".’
Content 2: \gsrc Inday daw ino paliten \textbf{sa}. | \gll Inday daw ino palit-en \textbf{sa}. | \gls don’t.know if/when what buy-T.IR D4NABS | \glt ‘(I) don’t know what \textbf{that} \textbf{one} will buy.’
Content 3: \gsrc Uyi na ubra Kagayanen nang gabuat \textbf{ti}. | \gll Uyi na ubra Kagayanen nang ga-buat \textbf{ti}. | \gls EMPH.D1ABS LK DO/work Kagayanen only I.R-do/make D1NABS | \glt ‘This work (special weave of mats) only Kagayanens do/make \textbf{this}.’
Content 4: \gsrc Tagan ki \textbf{sa}. | \gll ∅-atag-an ki \textbf{sa}. | \gls T.IR-give-APL 1P.INCL.ABS D4NABS | \glt ‘Give us some of \textbf{that}.’
Content 5: \gsrc Lasa \textbf{tan} sikad na tam-is | \gll Lasa \textbf{tan} sikad na tam-is… | \gls taste D3NABS very LK sweet | \glt ‘The taste \textbf{of} \textbf{that} is very sweet…’ (This text is describing a pineapple.)
Content 6: \gsrc Lain man nyan, bao \textbf{san} na agas a. | \gll Lain man nyan, bao \textbf{san} na agas a. | \gls bad EMPH D2PR odor D2NABS LK kerosene INJ | \glt ‘That is really bad, the odor \textbf{of} \textbf{that} kerosene.’

Knowledge Point: A pre-Head demonstrative adjective may occur alone as an absolutive Referring Expression only when it occurs in pre-predicate position (see examples \ref{bkm:Ref420931966} and \ref{bkm:Ref420931983} below). The usual function of demonstrative adjectives, however, is as pre-Head modifiers of RPs in any case role, in any allowable position.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Uyi} gid una na suwa ta Cagayan i. | \gll \textbf{U-yi} gid una na suwa ta Cagayan i. | \gls EMPH-D1ABS INT first LK citrus.fruit NABS Cagayan DEF.N | \glt ‘\textbf{This} really is the first citrus fruit on Cagayancillo.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Yon} masugid ko ki kyo. | \gll \textbf{Yon} ma-sugid ko ki kyo. | \gls D3ABS A.HAP.R-tell 1S.ERG OBL.P 2P.ABS | \glt ‘\textbf{That} is what I can tell you.’

Knowledge Point: The following is a rough template of the Kagayanen basic Referring Phrase. There is potential complexity within some of the elements displayed in \REF{bkm:Ref340905081}, as well as some co-occurrence restrictions and possible variations in order. These will be discussed in the following paragraphs and subsections.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In this template, CM refers to a set of case marking particles – zero for absolutive Referring Phrases and ta for non-absolutive Referring Phrases headed by common nouns (RPs headed by personal names are discussed in \sectref{sec:referringphrasesheadedbypersonalnames}). The PL element before MOD\textsubscript{1} indicates indefinite plural (\ref{bkm:Ref363459525}) while PL before the head is unspecified\textsubscript{} for definiteness (\ref{bkm:Ref414967349} and \ref{bkm:Ref414967351}). PL refers to the plural/collective particle pronounced [maŋá] but spelled mga following common practice in the Philippines for languages with similar particles (e.g., Tagalog [máŋa]). Both plural markers are optional even when the head is semantically plural (see example \ref{bkm:Ref363459636}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: When Є occurs, it is in the second position in MOD\textsubscript{1}. Thus, if MOD\textsubscript{1} consists of a single word, the Є complex immediately follows that word (see examples \ref{bkm:Ref447702060}{}--\ref{bkm:Ref447702062}). When MOD\textsubscript{1} is itself complex (e.g., a Modifier Phrase (see \chapref{chap:modification}) or a relative clause (\sectref{sec:rpscontainingrelativeclauses}), Є usually occurs after the first element. It is only when the modifier phrase includes an intensity adverb such as sikad ‘very’ initially that Є does not occur in second position. Rather, the intensity adverb and the adjective occur together and the genitive enclitic follows them. But when no MOD\textsubscript{1} is present, both elements of the optional enclitic (Є) complex follow the head.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: As indicated by the curly brackets (\{ \}) in \REF{bkm:Ref340905081}, MOD\textsubscript{1} plus the optional enclitic complex is in complementary distribution with a demonstrative adjective; both are “optional” and both are followed by the “linker” (LK) na. RP\textsubscript{gen} refers to another Referring Phrase functioning as a “possessor” of the Head.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The MOD\textsubscript{1} position may contain Modifier Phrases (\chapref{chap:modification}, \sectref{sec:modifierphrases}), Numeral Phrases (\chapref{chap:modification}, \sectref{bkm:Ref418107822}), quantifiers and free genitive pronouns (\sectref{sec:personalpronouns}), and nominalized verbs or “short” relative clauses (those having no more than one overt argument, which must be pronominal). The MOD\textsubscript{2} position may also contain Modifier Phrases and relative clauses, but less commonly numerals or quantifiers. “Long” relative clauses (those having one overt full RP argument, or more than one overt argument, either pronominal or full RP), may only occur in MOD\textsubscript{2}. When two modifiers simultaneously modify the same head, usually one is in MOD\textsubscript{1} and the other in MOD\textsubscript{2} or there are two MOD\textsubscript{2} positions (see examples \ref{bkm:Ref363459636}{}-\ref{bkm:Ref447702340}). RPs with more than two modifiers modifying a single head are not common but do occur. Usually there can be only one MOD\textsubscript{1}, but there can be up to three MOD\textsubscript{2} elements. When a RP has three modifiers then the linker in one of the linker positions is likely to drop out. Occasionally two MOD\textsubscript{1} elements occur, in which case the first must be a numeral and the second an adjective (\ref{bkm:Ref363460123}), but this also is not common.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: The following are a few additional examples of basic RPs from the corpus, with labels indicating the functions of the individual parts, as referenced in the template in \REF{bkm:Ref340905081}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The RP\textsubscript{gen} position may be filled by any genitive case RP, bolded in examples \REF{bkm:Ref447702935}-\REF{bkm:Ref363473619}. Only one expression of a possessor/genitive element modifying the head may occur in any RP. In other words, if a full RP\textsubscript{gen} occurs, enclitic genitives are precluded.
Content 1: \gsrc lieg ya \textbf{ta} \textbf{bata} \textbf{din} | \gll lieg ya \textbf{ta} \textbf{bata} \textbf{din} | \gls neck DEF.F NABS child 3S.GEN | \glt ‘the neck \textbf{of} \textbf{his} \textbf{child}’
Content 2: \gsrc ta mga ginikanan man \textbf{ta} \textbf{mga} \textbf{bag-o} \textbf{tao} \textbf{na} \textbf{bata} | \gll ta mga ginikanan man \textbf{ta} \textbf{mga} \textbf{bag-o} \textbf{tao} \textbf{na} \textbf{bata} | \gls NABS PL parent too NABS PL new born LK child | \glt ‘also parents \textbf{of} \textbf{newborn} \textbf{children}’

Knowledge Point: Finally, free genitive pronouns can occur in MOD\textsubscript{1} position (\ref{bkm:Ref447707029}{}-\ref{bkm:Ref343925554}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{ake} \textbf{ya} na duma | \gll \textbf{ake} \textbf{ya} na duma | \gls 1S.GEN DEF.F LK companion | \glt ‘\textbf{my} companion’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Pronominal genitives in MOD\textsubscript{1} often express a contrastive or emphatic sense, as in the second conjunct (RP2) of example \REF{bkm:Ref343925554}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Demonstrative adjectives can occur in MOD\textsubscript{1} \REF{bkm:Ref343578428}-\REF{singlewoman}, or in MOD\textsubscript{2} position \REF{bkm:Ref360182922}-\REF{bkm:Ref363547504}. In the following examples, the RP containing a demonstrative is bolded in the text and in its free translation:
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Yi} \textbf{na} \textbf{manakem} lipo na tise, piro tama nadlek ki kanen. | \gll \textbf{Yi} \textbf{na} \textbf{manakem} lipo na tise, piro tama na-adlek ki kanen. | \gls D1ABS LK older short LK small but many A.HAP.R-afraid OBL.P 3s | \glt ‘\textbf{This} \textbf{older} \textbf{person} is short and small, but many are afraid of her.’
Content 2: \gsrc Manakem \textbf{naya} kateļen. | \gll Manakem \textbf{naya} kateļ-en. | \gls older D3ABS itchy-ABS | \glt ‘\textbf{That} older one was very itchy with sores.’
Content 3: \gsrc mangngod ko \textbf{nai} na sise | \gll mangngod ko \textbf{nai} na sise | \gls younger.sibling 1S.GEN D1ABS LK small | \glt ‘\textbf{this} small younger sibling of mine’

Knowledge Point: When a demonstrative occurs in MOD\textsubscript{1}, an intensity, clausal or aspectual adverb such as man ‘also’ may occur after the demonstrative \REF{bkm:Ref342913658}.\footnote{We gloss the adverb man as ‘also’, which adequately captures its main function. However, depending on the context it may express the sense of ‘again’ or ‘same’ (as in example \ref{bkm:Ref342913658}). In other contexts, it may evoke excitement or strong feelings. The same form functions as a conjunction joining two RPs, two clauses or even higher level units. In that usage, it expresses none of the emotional overtones that accompany its adverbial usages.} Other words, including the enclitic demonstrative determiner, numerals, adjectives, free genitive pronouns or enclitic genitive pronouns do not co-occur with demonstratives in the same Referring Phrase (compare \ref{bkm:Ref447708043} and the ungrammatical or extremely awkward examples in \ref{bkm:Ref116485548}):
Content 1: \gsrc Ta \textbf{yo} \textbf{man} \textbf{na} \textbf{adlaw} sikad kay sadya. | \gll Ta \textbf{yo} \textbf{man} \textbf{na} \textbf{adlaw} sikad kay sadya. | \gls NABS D4ABS too LK day very 1P.EXCL.ABS fun/enjoy | \glt ‘On \textbf{that} \textbf{same} \textbf{day} we were very happy.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ta \textbf{yo} \textbf{man} \textbf{na} \textbf{adlaw} sikad kay sadya. | \gll Ta \textbf{yo} \textbf{man} \textbf{na} \textbf{adlaw} sikad kay sadya. | \gls NABS D4ABS too LK day very 1P.EXCL.ABS fun/enjoy | \glt ‘On \textbf{that} \textbf{same} \textbf{day} we were very happy.’
Content 3: \gsrc Yi man na bayo | \gll Yi man na bayo | \gls D41ABS too LK clothes/shirt | \glt ‘this shirt too’

Knowledge Point: A demonstrative may occur in MOD\textsubscript{2} (\ref{bkm:Ref360182922}-\ref{bkm:Ref363547504}), rather than MOD\textsubscript{1}. An enclitic genitive pronoun, mostly first person singular ko, and a postposed adjective may co-occur in the same Referring Phrase (\ref{bkm:Ref447709205} and \ref{bkm:Ref363547504}), but not a numeral, preposed adjective, free genitive pronoun or an enclitic demonstrative determiner (\ref{bkm:Ref447709215}). The linker na does not occur between the postposed demonstrative and the head since the postposed demonstratives are contractions of the linker na plus the basic demonstrative.
Content 1: \gsrc Manakem \textbf{naya} kateļen. | \gll Manakem \textbf{naya} kateļ-en. | \gls older D3ABS itchy-ABS | \glt ‘\textbf{That} older one was very itchy with sores.’
Content 2: \gsrc mangngod ko \textbf{nai} na sise | \gll mangngod ko \textbf{nai} na sise | \gls younger.sibling 1S.GEN D1ABS LK small | \glt ‘\textbf{this} small younger sibling of mine’
Content 3: \gsrc Gumangken ko \textbf{nai} gapadugang gid ta abilidad din | \gll Gumangken ko \textbf{nai} ga-pa-dugang gid ta abilidad din… | \gls niece/nephew 1S.GEN D1ABS I.R-CAUS-add INT NABS ability 3S.GEN | \glt `\textbf{This} nephew of mine really added to his ability…’
Content 4: \gsrc mangngod ko \textbf{nai} na sise | \gll mangngod ko \textbf{nai} na sise | \gls younger.sibling 1S.GEN D1ABS LK small | \glt ‘\textbf{this} small younger sibling of mine’

Subsection: Referring Phrases headed by nominalized clauses
Knowledge Point: The head of a Referring Phrase can be a verb root inflected with certain Transitivity/Modality (TM) affixes (see \chapref{chap:verbstructure}, \sectref{sec:verbinflection} on verb inflection), to form participant nominalizations\is{participant nominalizations} \citep[225]{payne1997}. In all such nominalizations, the resulting noun refers to the participant of the activity that would be the absolutive of the verb, given the TM affixes present. Example \REF{bkm:Ref117494864} lists participant nominalizations based on the root luto “cook”. In-context examples from the corpus are given further below.
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: Referring Phrases headed by nominalized clauses
Knowledge Point: Since participant nominalizations may have arguments, some linguists may describe them as (headless) relative clauses (see \chapref{chap:clausecombining}, \sectref{sec:relativeclauses}). The ambitransitive affixes (na{}- and ma-) create a noun that refers to the S or O argument of the verb (na- twice in example \ref{bkm:Ref447709957} and once in example \ref{bkm:Ref447710237}). Intransitive affixes create a noun that refers to the S (ga{}- in examples \ref{bkm:Ref447709957}, \ref{bkm:Ref417973067}, \ref{bkm:Ref417973212}, and mag{}- in \ref{bkm:Ref447710237}). Finally, the applicative plus transitive affixation forms a noun that refers to an applied O argument (\ref{bkm:Ref363550595}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Uļa en \textbf{magdamag} \textbf{ta} \textbf{mga} \textbf{napatay}. | \gll Uļa en \textbf{mag-damag} \textbf{ta} \textbf{mga} \textbf{na-patay} | \gls NEG.R CM I.IR-wake NABS PL A.HAP.R-die | \glt ‘There was \textbf{no} \textbf{one} \textbf{who} \textbf{will} \textbf{attend} \textbf{the} \textbf{wake} of \textbf{the} \textbf{ones} \textbf{who} \textbf{had} \textbf{died}.’
Content 4: \gsrc Pag-abot nay \textbf{ta} \textbf{gaubra} \textbf{ta} \textbf{karsada} dayon din angad operator ya daw ambaļen ta Visaya na ambaļ... | \gll Pag--abot nay \textbf{ta} \textbf{ga-ubra} \textbf{ta} \textbf{karsada} dayon din angad operator ya daw ambaļ-en ta Visaya na ambaļ... | \gls NR.ACT-arrive 1P.EXCL.GEN NABS I.R-work NABS road right.away 3S.ERG look.up operator DEF.F and say-T.IR NABS Visayan LK say | \glt `When we arrived at \textbf{the} \textbf{one} \textbf{working} \textbf{on} \textbf{the} \textbf{road}, then he looked up at the operator (of the construction machinery) and said in the Visayan language…’
Content 5: \gsrc Daw mga pamilya \textbf{ta} \textbf{napatay} \textbf{an} gasake ta imes \textbf{ta} \textbf{mga} \textbf{ubraén} paryas ta kaoy na buaten na kabaong. | \gll Daw mga pamilya \textbf{ta} \textbf{na-patay} \textbf{an} ga-sake ta imes \textbf{ta} \textbf{mga} \textbf{ubra-én} paryas ta kaoy na buat-en na kabaong. | \gls and PL family NABS A.HAP.R-die DEF.M I.R-busy NABS prepare NABS PL work-NR like NABS wood LK make-T.IR LK coffin | \glt `And the family \textbf{of} \textbf{the} \textbf{one} \textbf{who} \textbf{died} are busy preparing \textbf{for} \textbf{the} \textbf{work} \textbf{that} \textbf{will} \textbf{be} \textbf{done,} such as the wood to make a coffin.’
Content 6: \gsrc Uļa en \textbf{magdamag} \textbf{ta} \textbf{mga} \textbf{napatay}. | \gll Uļa en \textbf{mag-damag} \textbf{ta} \textbf{mga} \textbf{na-patay} | \gls NEG.R CM I.IR-wake NABS PL A.HAP.R-die | \glt ‘There was \textbf{no} \textbf{one} \textbf{who} \textbf{will} \textbf{attend} \textbf{the} \textbf{wake} of \textbf{the} \textbf{ones} \textbf{who} \textbf{had} \textbf{died}.’
Content 7: \gsrc \textbf{Uļa-uļaan} \textbf{an} pirmi tampek ta pantad. | \gll \textbf{Uļa\~uļa-an} \textbf{an} pirmi tampek ta pantad. | \gls RED\~spill/drain/pour-APL DEF.M always pack.on NABS sand | \glt ‘Sand was always packed on \textbf{where} \textbf{liquid} \textbf{drains} \textbf{out}.’

Knowledge Point: MOD\textsubscript{1} may contain a relative clause consisting only of a verb and up to one pronominal argument. Such “short” relative clauses may also appear in MOD\textsubscript{2} (\ref{bkm:Ref360181429}). In the following examples, the short relative clauses are given in brackets. Additional discussion and examples of relative clauses is provided in \chapref{chap:clausecombining}, \sectref{sec:relativeclauses}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: As in basic RPs, a plural marker mga may occur before the relative clause in MOD\textsubscript{1} indicating indefinite plural (\ref{bkm:Ref447714036} and \ref{bkm:Ref421109060}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Longer relative clauses---those containing at least one full RP---must occur in MOD\textsubscript{2}. In example \REF{bkm:Ref117497845}, the relative clause (bracketed) contains the RP ta ummay na inog ‘ripe rice’ and so it must follow the Head, baboy an ‘the pig’:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The absolutive case is unmarked for common nouns and personal names. Since both the actor (\isi{ergative}) personal name and the \isi{absolutive} undergoer are unmarked, when both occur in one clause, their roles are distinguished only by order (\ref{bkm:Ref329345305})---the Actor is always first and the Undergoer second.
Content 1: \gsrc Pasugo \textbf{Manang} \textbf{Pedro} an na mandok. | \gll Pa-sugo ∅ \textbf{Manang} ∅ \textbf{Pedro} an na m-sandok. | \gls T.R-order ERG.P older.sister ABS.P Pedro DEF.M LK I.V.IR-carry.water | \glt ‘\textbf{Older-sister} ordered \textbf{Pedro} to carry water.’

Knowledge Point: Though there are no case markers preceding either of the core arguments in \REF{bkm:Ref329345305}, the interpretation is unambiguous as to who is ordering whom to carry water. First, there is a strong preference for ergative arguments to precede other arguments, especially when proper names are involved. Second, the demonstrative determiner an, though not required, reinforces the idea that Pedro is the absolutive argument, therefore the Patient/Causee. Third, pragmatically a younger person (Pedro) could not conceivably order his older sister to do something.
Content 1: \gsrc Pasugo \textbf{Manang} \textbf{Pedro} an na mandok. | \gll Pa-sugo ∅ \textbf{Manang} ∅ \textbf{Pedro} an na m-sandok. | \gls T.R-order ERG.P older.sister ABS.P Pedro DEF.M LK I.V.IR-carry.water | \glt ‘\textbf{Older-sister} ordered \textbf{Pedro} to carry water.’

Knowledge Point: In conversation the plural marker is often left out, especially when plurality is obvious. For example, in \REF{bkm:Ref447720182} the RP ittaw i na malain ‘people who are bad’ has no plural marker but it is obvious that this is plural from the 3\textsuperscript{rd} person plural pronoun danen after the verb referring to the same people.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Personal names can be marked for plural with plural pronouns, in which case the RP refers to the person named and some group of associates, for example, danen Maria `Maria and them/family/companions/associates', danen Papa `Dad and them/family/companions/associates' (see \sectref{sec:referringphrasesheadedbypersonalnames}, examples \ref{bkm:Ref53060834} and \ref{bkm:Ref343578640}). Referring Phrases can also be pluralized with numerals, quantifiers, collective nouns, and with two adjectives that have specialized plural forms – sise/siset ‘small’, derse/derset ‘small.\textsc{pl}’ (\ref{bkm:Ref447720514}), and bakod ‘big’, darko ‘big.\textsc{pl}’ (examples \ref{bkm:Ref447720545} and \ref{bkm:Ref447720547}). Collections or groups can also be specified morphologically, for example, bata ‘child’, bataan ‘group of children usually with the same parents’ kabataan ‘groups or many children usually having different parents’ (see \sectref{sec:ka-an} above). The plural marker mga is optional when there is a plural form of a numeral, quantifier or adjective:
Content 1: \gsrc Kamusta nang en \textbf{ki} \textbf{danen} \textbf{Maria}. | \gll Kamusta nang en \textbf{ki} \textbf{danen} \textbf{Maria}. | \gls greeting only CM OBL.P 3P Maria | \glt ‘Greetings \textbf{to} \textbf{Maria} \textbf{and} \textbf{companions}.’ (The word nang ‘only’ in this example indicates politeness.)
Content 2: \gsrc Na abot kay en naan ta baļay, gatingaļa en \textbf{danen} \textbf{Papa} tak ubos kay ta basa. | \gll Na\footnotemark{} ∅-abot kay en naan ta baļay, ga-tingaļa en \textbf{danen} \textbf{Papa} tak ubos kay ta basa. | \gls LK I.R-arrive 1P.EXCL.ABS CM SPAT.DEF NABS house I.R-wonder CM 3P.ABS Papa because all 1P.EXCL.ABS NABS wet | \glt `When we arrived at the house, \textbf{Papa} \textbf{and} \textbf{companions} were wondering because all of us were wet.’ CBWN-C-10 4.42
Content 3: \gsrc Tapos lungagan ta \textbf{derset} \textbf{na} \textbf{lungag} para makasingngaw daw magsikaļ waig an. | \gll Tapos ∅-lungag-an ta \textbf{derset} \textbf{na} \textbf{lungag} para maka-singngaw daw mag-sikaļ waig an. | \gls then T.IR-hole-APL NABS small.PL LK hole PURP I.CAUS.HAP.IR-evaporate if/when I.IR-boil water DEF.M | \glt `Then make \textbf{small} \textbf{holes} (in the can) for the purpose of the water evaporating out when boiling.’
Content 5: \gsrc Unsi bilog na \textbf{darko} \textbf{na} \textbf{sidda} igo nang layungan ta appat na bataan. | \gll Unsi bilog na \textbf{darko} \textbf{na} \textbf{sidda} igo nang ∅-layung-an ta appat na bata-an. | \gls eleven round LK big.PL LK fish right just T.IR-carry.on.pole-APL NABS four LK child-NR | \glt `Eleven \textbf{big} \textbf{fish} is just right for four children to carry between them (on a pole over the shoulders).’

Knowledge Point: Absolutive nouns frequently occur with a determiner, but not obligatorily. RPs in all other roles can also occur with these forms. In other words, these are not case markers (contra \citealt{harmon1977}). The demonstrative determiners can also occur on genitive and oblique common nouns (\ref{ex:prison}-\ref{ex:night}). Any common noun that occurs clause finally preferentially takes a determiner (see example \ref{bkm:Ref447721085} and many others below). The ergative element is usually already introduced into the story and so does not need to be marked with a definite marker. However, sometimes a definite marker does occur in an ergative RP (\ref{ex:woman}-\ref{ex:snake}). There are also discourse functions for i, an, and ya that involve staging of participants \citep{pebleyenclitic1999}. They cannot occur with other demonstrative elements in the same RP.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In addition to their usages in RPs headed by common nouns, the demonstrative determiners also occur when the Head is an absolutive proper name or absolutive free personal pronoun. When the RP head is a proper name or personal pronoun, the three determiners do not indicate definiteness since these are already definite. Rather they indicate only the location in space and time (see examples \ref{bkm:Ref447721085}, and \ref{bkm:Ref447721088}-\ref{bkm:Ref447721090}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
